Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 10:25PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: I had an MRI that detected a minuscule lump. They didn't think it would turn out to be anything, nut wanted to err in the side of caution. They attempted to biopsy guided by ultrasound, but the bugger hid. Back to the MRI for a biopsy. Even then they were 90% certain it was fat necrosis. Their caution paid off--it was ILC. In addition to the IDC already biopsied. That changed our plan from lumpectomy to MX. There can be a very good reason to use the MRI first. My surgery is May 27th.
Posts.Title: Worth the wait for MRI and BRCA results? dianamaps whatsnext

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 01:14PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: In the chair now. All has been EASY. One thing I was not prepared for--the Decadron (steroid) IV gave my arms and legs the heebie jeebies. The nurses were laughing themselves silly when I came in with my rolling cooler of water bottles and ice packs. I did ice my fingers and toes!! I had a Mani/pedi yesterday using Sally Hansen. AND I got a facial. I figured pampering was in order. I bought all of my supplies--not cheap, but worth every penny. Today I am so glad for my port!!!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 07:18PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: vinrph---my polish for fingers and toes is "Back to the Fuschia". Hot Pink!!!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 12:38PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Day 2 post cocktail chair: I'm tired. Pretty sure it was the whole Xanax I took with my two Decadron last night. My taste buds are shot to hell. Even water tastes bad. I had to switch to sparkling water to cut the bad taste. I have a touch if heartburn, but that is easily remedied. My biggest issue is taste. I'm hungry and little tastes good or is remotely appealing. I think I might have a touch of the steroid irritability/depression. My mother is on my last nerve. I commented how tired I felt and she piped up in her Joan of Arc sing-song voice, "well that's just when you just push on through it". Then she gave me a list if calls I needed to make and fussed and ranted an hour later that i hadn't done them. Helloooo--I managed to take a shower and out corned on. I'm getting there. Today is just a slow day. Now I want to cry. And she looks at me smugly.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2011 06:48AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: re: Alcohol.  I had 2 glasses of wine and a glass of Prosecco AGAIN last night and I have to say...DAMN, it tasted GOOD.  I'm conscious of taking in enough fluids, but water tastes like crap, the bubbles fill me up and everything else is loaded with sugar and I despise artificial sweeteners.  So wine it was....I was on Cloud Nine.  AND I slept like a baby.  Side Note:  I really thought my period was gone.  In fact, Wednesday night I was discussing with someone the joy of it being gone.  That karma is a real bitch because doncha know it--it arrived yesterday and by last night it was in full force.  Borderline TMI here:  by the time I got to work, I had flooded and it was running down my leg.  Grrrrrrrrrrrrrr.....menopause, where are you?????
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 07:41AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Oh MrsMot---I sooooooo understand the explosion!!!  I took a BIG gulp of MoM last night before bed and woke up at 3:30 to open the gates to the dam.  30 minutes of "peeing".  LOL  Such TMI.  I agree about all of the OTC expense.  Whew!!!  I did my 3rd round yesterday and I think I might finally have a good handle on the SE's...just when it is almot over.  vtEllen:  My onc and her staff laughed heartily at me when I arrived for my first round---it looked like I had packed for a week.  I had everything with me but the kitchen sink.  Just finished round 3 and I now carry about 25% of what I did.  I still bring more than the rest of their patients.  LOL

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2011 10:35AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: revmama---I am with Chickadee.  Biotene toothpaste.  I don't know what I would do with out it.  I brush 3x a day now.  Won't my dentist love me!  And congrats on graduating!  I will join you in just one week.  I am so stinking excited.  I am ready to move on!

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2011 02:16AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: C'est finis!!!! #4 is under my belt---no more poison to course through my veins!! Woo Hoo!!! By Friday night I will slipping into my cave and Irene will provide the rainy pleasure to carry me through my down weekend. MrsMot: glad to hear you are on the mend. You CAN do it.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2011 11:39AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Checking back in with the T/C June 2011 crowd...I didn't mind my first round in the lounge chair. Day 3 was my bad day--absolute fatigue and unable to sleep. No nausea, vomitting or even queasiness. I have great spurts of energy and then I bottom out. My hair started shedding on Day 14---a bit earlier than I expected. I commented to my coworker that my hair was falling out--she said it didn't look any thinner (I have thick hair). I told her to hold on a sec----I spread paper out across the table then shook my head over it. We both laughed when it was covered with hair. I guess I have plenty too lose. I'm really hoping to make it through the weekend with my hair. I have a pool party on Sunday and am just not ready for THAT to be my breakthrough moment of showing up in a wig, a wrap, or a bald head. I may not have a choice. My scalp seems to ache---somewhere between a sunburn and pins and needles. When it started I predicted that my hair would start its retreat. I have been lucky to avoid the acne for the most part. I have a giant underground knot on my jawline, but that's about it. Most of my acne is induced by whiskers---and since my hair is coming out, hopefully the whiskers will go away too!! I have found the my skin is much drier and crepe-ier. Bringing on the heavy moisturizer. I don't recall my MO saying anything about alcohol, but I will admit to have a glass of prosecco the other night and it tasted FABULOUS. Since just about every beverage tastes like crap, bubbles are my saving grace, usually just sparking water. But the prosecco was such a divine indulgence. I guess time will tell when I get my blood work done next week. ;-) Best wishes to everyone getting their time in the lounge chair this week!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 05:45PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Hey MrsMot, I feel your colon pain.  For some reason, round 2 was MUCH harder on my colon.  I made my Miralax cocktail, gobbled colace like M & M's and I went through pure HELL today trying to "unload".  I have made progress, but I have yet to "clean house".  For as rotten as I feel today (my down day), I think I would feel at least 50% better if I could poop like a normal person.  Is that TMI?????  LOL
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 07:34AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: vtEllen---Nausea has been a non-issue for me.  That was my biggest concern at the beginning.  You envision the stereotypical "Hollywood" cancer patient:  gray skin, dark circles under the eyes, gaunt, wrapped in a shawl, throwing up.  That is all Hollywood.  The way they bundle your infusion, you really shouldn't feel much nausea, if any at all.  The steroids you take and the Zofran in your infusion really should take care of it.  I have a prescription for Zofran, but I really haven't needed it. My greatest issue outside of the absolute fatigue that others have discussed is constipation.  The chemo really locks things up for me.  I have had Mirilax and Colace and I wasn't satisfied.  As I gear up for round 3 on Wednesday, I am going to add something else to my bag of tricks.  Someone recommended Milk of Magnesia to me.  I tried it this weekend.  I think it may do the trick.  It kind of sends things the other direction, but I would rather be "loose" than not go at all. I wish you the best of luck and you begin the journey.  I honestly don't believe that it is as bad as we all think it will be.  Keep positive thoughts, relax, get your head and heart in a good place.  You CAN do it.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 09:15PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: My thoughts on Neulasta: I injected myself yesterday. I took Zyrtec. Plenty. Yesterday and today. My surgical sites ACHE. I had a BMX and DIEP, a port, AND surgery to repair my quad tendon (knee). Each site is aching. And I need to POOP. Colace and Miralax. Not hitting it yet. Ugh.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 11:57AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Aahhhhh...the beauty of this website!!  I, too, have had the drippy nose and sore throat.  I've been so fearful of thrush that I use the Biotene regularly AND use the Biotene tooth paste too.  I'm 14 days post #2---this is when I feel fabulous and seem to forget that I am still a patient.  I love being able to check in here and feel "normal".  Thank you to EVERYONE!

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 10:06PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: I start on June 22.  My biggest fear is the exercise.  In the middle of all of this BC mess, I slipped on wet grass and ruptured my quad tendon---the most pain I have ever had, worse than my BMX and DIEP.  So I have lots of healing going on and am still trying to regain the range of motion in my left leg.  I have my head wrapped around the chemo part and am ok with everything.  Now I am trying to process all of the potential side effects.  Steroids = acne?  Say it ain't so!!!  I read somewhere about your fingernails going to hell in a handbasket but that there was something you could put on them that would prevent it---if only I could remember what it was or where I read it.  Any suggestions?
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 11:39AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Ok, round 2 complete.  I hate giving myself the Neulasta, but the hospital is 45 minutes away and that is a silly drive for an injection.  It took me two stabs last night to do it.  I think I am more tired and achey on round 2 than round 1.  Someone described it best that the anxiety of knowing what is coming really kicks our butts worse than what it really is. I have extra stress on board because I have gone back to work and they are all uncomortable (men) with the fact that I am sick and are freaked out.  There is a 400 lb fat man that took the opportunity to tell me what I was eating for lunch (a hoagie) was not healthy---as he sat there eating a Lean Cuisine filled with chemicals.  Then he suggested I make changes to my diet, then went as far as suggesting that my cancer was cause by my diet.  A coworker changed the subject to my relief, only for the fat man to bring it back.  He then started laughing saying that he had three sisters and knew how to push my buttons.  My blood pressure has been soaring since.  And our boss (male) is not inclined to say anything to him because it will just "get his German" up.  So my feelings don't matter, only the fat man's.  Actually my boss told another coworker that he would be happy if nothing was ever mentioned about what I am going through---kind of like pretend it isn't happening.  This is a small office---it is the elephant in the room.  So in retaliation, I have refused to wear a wig.  I wear a scarf every day.  In your face.  ;-)
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 07:47PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: Rev----my heart goes out to you with this difficult decision.  Hoping you'll go with the rads for the extra insurance.  Lots of prayers headed your way while you wrestle with this.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan starting June 2011 vlnrph chickadee521

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 11:10AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: REV!!!  SOOOOOOOOOOOO happy with your decision.  We will be your cheerleaders!!!!!!! Yeah Rev!! R-E-V   Goooooooooo REV!!!!  Woo Hoo!!!!!  I would do a backflip if I could.   MrsMot:  I hope this finds you with normal hands and a hiveless body.  I never got hives, but I am prone to ginormous cankles.  Doesn't feel good.  I take an enormous dose of Lasix to counteract it.  I could sit on the toilet all day long and just tinkle.  Inconvenient, no? VinRPH:  Welcome back to the working world!!  Take it easy and don't hesitate to call it when you are tired.  I went back to work after round 1.  But then again, I had the luxury of sitting at a desk in an office and ignoring the rest of the world.  I'll be praying for energy for you on Tuesday.  I don't remember (CHEMO BRAIN) if I mentioned that I escaped having to do my final Neulasta because throughout my numbers were great.  I have to admit, in hindsight, I now realize that the Neulasta, despite taking Claritin, really did enhance my achiness.  I did not feel nearly as BAD, though this last round really caught up to me.  I was POOPED.  And my tastes buds are STILL off.   I keep telling everyone that I cannot wait to feel NORMAL again---I don't know if I remember what normal is, but I want my taste buds and my energy level back.  I'm doing PT 2x/week for my BMX.  I desperately want my strength and range of motion back.   Like a toddler discovering independence, I want to be able to do things MYSELF.  Believe it or not, I'm a bit tired of being waited on and catered to.  I want to be normal.  Seriously.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 11:44AM CrimsonQ66 wrote: bcisnofun--I am 5 weeks PFC tomorrow and the whiskers on my chin are appearing rapidly.  I need to shave my legs, though not as often and I have a glorious waft of peach fuzz covering my head.  The back is coming in fast than the front.  I would like a lit more on my head so that I can truly go topless.  I have gotten in the habit of yanking off my scarf while I am sitting at my desk.  Sometimes I forget to put it back on and only realize it when I see the shocked faces.  Soon enough, we'll have hair, too.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 11:31PM CrimsonQ66 wrote: WorkingMom: congrats on your decision. I am 4 weeks out from BMX and DIEP. NO REGRETS!!! during the first two days following surgery I kept saying "this isn't a walk in the park and certainly isn't a picnic". But I have to be honest--it gets better. I am also recovering from a ruptured quad tendon. I can only think if I had two good legs, this adventure would gave been that much better. I started chemo today and I still feel great, though I know that will change in a few days v My best recommendation in to make sure you get plenty of Colace in the hospital. It is important to get your colon awake and moving for optimum comfort. You CAN do this and it will be OK. You will be surprised at the inner strength you can summon when you most need it. Best of luck to you!!!
